018import java.util.Map;
019import java.util.List;
020import java.util.ArrayList;
021import java.util.Collections;
022import java.util.HashMap;
023import java.util.Locale;
024import java.util.Objects;
025import java.text.Format;
026import java.text.FieldPosition;
027import java.text.ParsePosition;
028import java.text.ParseException;
029import java.util.ResourceBundle;
030import java.util.MissingResourceException;
031import java.util.ConcurrentModificationException;
032import java.io.IOException;
033import javax.measure.Dimension;
034import javax.measure.Unit;
035import javax.measure.format.ParserException;
036import tech.uom.seshat.math.Fraction;
037import tech.uom.seshat.math.MathFunctions;
038import tech.uom.seshat.resources.Errors;
039import tech.uom.seshat.util.Characters;
040import tech.uom.seshat.util.CharSequences;
041import tech.uom.seshat.util.WeakValueHashMap;

043
044/**
045 * Parses and formats units of measurement as SI symbols, URI in OGC namespace or other symbols.
046 * This class combines in a single class the API from {@link java.text} and the API from {@link javax.measure.format}.
047 * In addition to the symbols of the <cite>Système international</cite> (SI), this class is also capable to handle
048 * some symbols found in <cite>Well Known Text</cite> (WKT) definitions or in XML files.
049 *
050 * <div class="section">Multi-threading</div>
051 * {@code UnitFormat} is generally not thread-safe. If units need to be parsed or formatted in different threads,
052 * each thread should have its own {@code UnitFormat} instance.
053 *
054 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
055 * @version 1.0
056 *
057 * @see Units#valueOf(String)
058 */
059public class UnitFormat extends Format implements javax.measure.format.UnitFormat {
060    /**
061     * For cross-version compatibility.
062     */
063    private static final long serialVersionUID = -3064428584419360693L;
064
065    /**
066     * The unit name for degrees (not necessarily angular), to be handled in a special way.
067     * Must contain only ASCII lower case letters ([a … z]).
068     */
069    private static final String DEGREES = "degrees";
070
071    /**
072     * The unit name for dimensionless unit.
073     */
074    private static final String UNITY = "unity";
075
076    /**
077     * The default instance used by {@link Units#valueOf(String)} for parsing units of measurement.
078     * While {@code UnitFormat} is generally not thread-safe, this particular instance is safe if
079     * we never invoke any setter method and we do not format with {@link Style#NAME}.
080     */
081    static final UnitFormat INSTANCE = new UnitFormat();
082
083    /**
084     * The locale specified at construction time or modified by {@link #setLocale(Locale)}.
085     *
086     * @see #getLocale()
087     */
088    private Locale locale;
089
090    /**
091     * Whether this {@code UnitFormat} should format long names like "metre" or use unit symbols.
092     *
093     * @see #getStyle()
094     */
095    private Style style;
096
097    /**
098     * Identify whether unit formatting uses ASCII symbols, Unicode symbols or full localized names.
099     * For example the {@link Units#CUBIC_METRE} units can be formatted in the following ways:
100     *
101     * <ul>
102     *   <li>As a symbol using Unicode characters: <b>m³</b></li>
103     *   <li>As a symbol restricted to the ASCII characters set: <b>m3</b></li>
104     *   <li>As a long name:<ul>
105     *     <li>in English: <cite>cubic metre</cite></li>
106     *     <li>in French: <cite>mètre cube</cite></li>
107     *   </ul></li>
108     * </ul>
109     *
110     * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
111     */
112    public enum Style {
113        /**
114         * Format unit symbols using Unicode characters. Units formatted in this style use superscript digits
115         * for exponents (as in “m³”), the dot operator (“⋅”) for multiplications, specialized characters when
116         * they exist (e.g. U+212A “K” for Kelvin sign), <i>etc.</i>
117         *
118         * <p>This is the default style of {@link UnitFormat}.</p>
119         *
120         * @see Unit#getSymbol()
121         */
122        SYMBOL(AbstractUnit.MULTIPLY, AbstractUnit.DIVIDE),
123
124        /**
125         * Format unit symbols using a syntax close to the Unified Code for Units of Measure (UCUM) one.
126         * The character set is restricted to ASCII. The multiplication operator is the period (“.”).
127         *
128         * <div class="section">Modification to UCUM syntax rules</div>
129         * UCUM does not allow floating point numbers in unit terms, so the use of period as an operator
130         * should not be ambiguous. However Seshat relaxes this restriction in order to support the
131         * scale factors commonly found in angular units (e.g. π/180). The meaning of a period in a string
132         * is resolved with two Seshat-specific rules:
133         *
134         * <ul>
135         *   <li>Unit symbols shall not begin or end with a decimal digit or a superscript.</li>
136         *   <li>A period between two decimal digits is interpreted as a decimal separator.</li>
137         * </ul>
138         */
139        UCUM('.', '/') {
140            /** Replace non-ASCII characters on a "best effort" basis. */
141            @Override Appendable appendSymbol(final Appendable toAppendTo, final String value) throws IOException {
142                if (value.startsWith("°")) {
143                    final int length = value.length();
144                    if (length == 2) {
145                        switch (value.charAt(1)) {
146                            case 'C': return toAppendTo.append("Cel");
147                            case 'K': // U+212A (Kelvin symbol)
148                            case 'K': return toAppendTo.append('K');
149                        }
150                    }
151                    return toAppendTo.append("deg").append(value, 1, length);
152                }
153                final CharSequence cs = CharSequences.toASCII(value);
154                final int length = cs.length();
155                for (int i=0; i<length; i++) {
156                    toAppendTo.append((char) Characters.toNormalScript(cs.charAt(i)));
157                }
158                return toAppendTo;
159            }
160
161            /** Formats the power for a unit symbol. */
162            @Override void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final int power) throws IOException {
163                toAppendTo.append(String.valueOf(power));
164            }
165
166            /** Actually illegal for UCUM, but at least ensure that it contains only ASCII characters. */
167            @Override void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final Fraction power) throws IOException {
168                toAppendTo.append(EXPONENT).append(OPEN).append(String.valueOf(power.numerator))
169                           .append('/').append(String.valueOf(power.denominator)).append(CLOSE);
170            }
171        },
172
173        /**
174         * Format unit symbols as localized long names if known, or Unicode symbols otherwise.
175         *
176         * @see Unit#getName()
177         */
178        NAME(AbstractUnit.MULTIPLY, AbstractUnit.DIVIDE);
179
180        /**
181         * Other symbols not in the {@link Style} enumeration because common to all.
182         */
183        static final char EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY = '*', EXPONENT = '^', OPEN = '(', CLOSE = ')';
184
185        /**
186         * Symbols to use for unit multiplications or divisions.
187         */
188        final char multiply, divide;
189
190        /**
191         * Creates a new style using the given symbols.
192         */
193        private Style(final char multiply, final char divide) {
194            this.multiply = multiply;
195            this.divide   = divide;
196        }
197
198        /**
199         * Appends a string that may contains Unicode characters. The enumeration is responsible
200         * for converting the Unicode characters into ASCII ones if needed.
201         */
202        Appendable appendSymbol(final Appendable toAppendTo, final String value) throws IOException {
203            return toAppendTo.append(value);
204        }
205
206        /**
207         * Appends an integer power. The power may be added as an exponent if allowed by the format style.
208         */
209        void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final int power) throws IOException {
210            if (power >= 0 && power <= 9) {
211                toAppendTo.append(Characters.toSuperScript((char) (power + '0')));
212            } else {
213                toAppendTo.append(String.valueOf(power));
214            }
215        }
216
217        /**
218         * Appends a rational power.
219         */
220        void appendPower(final Appendable toAppendTo, final Fraction power) throws IOException {
221            toAppendTo.append(EXPONENT);
222            final String value = power.toString();
223            if (value.length() == 1) {
224                toAppendTo.append(value);
225            } else {
226                toAppendTo.append(OPEN).append(value).append(CLOSE);
227            }
228        }
229    }
230
231    /**
232     * Symbols or names to use for formatting units in replacement to the default unit symbols or names.
233     * The {@link Unit} instances are the ones specified by user in calls to {@link #label(Unit, String)}.
234     *
235     * @see #label(Unit, String)
236     */
237    private Map<Unit<?>,String> unitToLabel;
238
239    /**
240     * Units associated to a given label (in addition to the system-wide {@link UnitRegistry}).
241     * This map is the converse of {@link #unitToLabel}. The {@link Unit} instances may differ from the ones
242     * specified by user since {@link AbstractUnit#symbol} may have been set to the label specified by the user.
243     * The labels may contain some characters normally not allowed in unit symbols, like white spaces.
244     *
245     * @see #label(Unit, String)
246     */
247    private final Map<String,Unit<?>> labelToUnit;
248
249    /**
250     * The mapping from unit symbols to long localized names.
251     * Those resources are locale-dependent and loaded when first needed.
252     *
253     * @see #symbolToName()
254     */
255    private transient volatile ResourceBundle symbolToName;
256
257    /**
258     * Mapping from long localized and unlocalized names to unit instances.
259     * This map is used only for parsing and created when first needed.
260     *
261     * @see #fromName(String)
262     */
263    private transient volatile Map<String,Unit<?>> nameToUnit;
264
265    /**
266     * Cached values of {@link #nameToUnit}, for avoiding to load the same information many time and for saving memory
267     * if the user create many {@code UnitFormat} instances. Note that we do not cache {@link #symbolToName} because
268     * {@link ResourceBundle} already provides its own caching mechanism.
269     *
270     * @see #fromName(String)
271     */
272    private static final WeakValueHashMap<Locale, Map<String,Unit<?>>> SHARED = new WeakValueHashMap<>(Locale.class);
273
274    /**
275     * Creates the unique {@link #INSTANCE}.
276     */
277    private UnitFormat() {
278        locale      = Locale.ROOT;
279        style       = Style.SYMBOL;
280        unitToLabel = Collections.emptyMap();
281        labelToUnit = Collections.emptyMap();
282    }
283
284    /**
285     * Creates a new format for the given locale.
286     *
287     * @param  locale  the locale to use for parsing and formatting units.
288     */
289    public UnitFormat(final Locale locale) {
290        Objects.requireNonNull(locale);
291        this.locale = locale;
292        style       = Style.SYMBOL;
293        unitToLabel = new HashMap<>();
294        labelToUnit = new HashMap<>();
295    }
296
297    /**
298     * Returns the locale used by this {@code UnitFormat}.
299     *
300     * @return the locale of this {@code UnitFormat}.
301     */
302    public Locale getLocale() {
303        return locale;
304    }
305
306    /**
307     * Sets the locale that this {@code UnitFormat} will use for long names.
308     * For example a call to <code>setLocale({@linkplain Locale#US})</code>
309     * instructs this formatter to use the “meter” spelling instead of “metre”.
310     *
311     * @param  locale  the new locale for this {@code UnitFormat}.
312     */
313    public void setLocale(final Locale locale) {
314        Objects.requireNonNull(locale);
315        this.locale  = locale;
316        symbolToName = null;            // Force reloading for the new locale.
317        nameToUnit   = null;
318    }
319
320    /**
321     * Returns whether this {@code UnitFormat} depends on the {@link Locale} given at construction time
322     * for performing its tasks. This method returns {@code true} if formatting long names (e.g. “metre”
323     * or “meter”} and {@code false} if formatting only the unit symbol (e.g. “m”).
324     *
325     * @return {@code true} if formatting depends on the locale.
326     */
327    @Override
328    public boolean isLocaleSensitive() {
329        return style == Style.NAME;
330    }
331
332    /**
333     * Returns whether unit formatting uses ASCII symbols, Unicode symbols or full localized names.
334     *
335     * @return the style of units formatted by this {@code UnitFormat} instance.
336     */
337    public Style getStyle() {
338        return style;
339    }
340
341    /**
342     * Sets whether unit formatting should use ASCII symbols, Unicode symbols or full localized names.
343     *
344     * @param  style  the desired style of units.
345     */
346    public void setStyle(final Style style) {
347        Objects.requireNonNull(style);
348        this.style = style;
349    }
350
351    /**
352     * Attaches a label to the specified unit. A <cite>label</cite> can be a substitute to either the
353     * {@linkplain AbstractUnit#getSymbol() unit symbol} or the {@link AbstractUnit#getName() unit name},
354     * depending on the {@linkplain #getStyle() format style}.
355     * If the specified label is already associated to another unit, then the previous association is discarded.
356     *
357     * <div class="section">Restriction on character set</div>
358     * Current implementation accepts only {@linkplain Character#isLetter(int) letters},
359     * {@linkplain Characters#isSubScript(int) subscripts}, {@linkplain Character#isSpaceChar(int) spaces}
360     * (including non-breaking spaces but not CR/LF characters),
361     * the degree sign (°) and a few other characters like underscore.
362     * The set of legal characters may be expanded in future Seshat versions,
363     * but the following restrictions are likely to remain:
364     *
365     * <ul>
366     *   <li>The following characters are reserved since they have special meaning in UCUM format, in URI
367     *       or in Seshat parser: <blockquote>" # ( ) * + - . / : = ? [ ] { } ^ ⋅ ∕</blockquote></li>
368     *   <li>The symbol can not begin or end with digits, since such digits would be confused with unit power.</li>
369     * </ul>
370     *
371     * @param  unit   the unit being labeled.
372     * @param  label  the new label for the given unit.
373     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given label is not a valid unit name.
374     */
375    @Override
376    public void label(final Unit<?> unit, String label) {
377        Objects.requireNonNull(unit);
378        label = label.trim();
379        for (int i=0; i < label.length();) {
380            final int c = label.codePointAt(i);
381            if (!AbstractUnit.isSymbolChar(c) && !Character.isSpaceChar(c)) {       // NOT Character.isWhitespace(int)
382                throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.IllegalArgumentValue_2, "label", label));
383            }
384            i += Character.charCount(c);
385        }
386        Unit<?> labeledUnit = unit;
387        if (labeledUnit instanceof ConventionalUnit<?>) {
388            labeledUnit = ((ConventionalUnit<?>) labeledUnit).forSymbol(label);
389        }
390        final Unit<?> unitForOldLabel = labelToUnit.remove(unitToLabel.put(unit, label));
391        final Unit<?> oldUnitForLabel = labelToUnit.put(label, labeledUnit);
392        if (oldUnitForLabel != null && !oldUnitForLabel.equals(labeledUnit) && !label.equals(unitToLabel.remove(oldUnitForLabel))) {
393            /*
394             * Assuming there is no bug in our algorithm, this exception should never happen
395             * unless this UnitFormat has been modified concurrently in another thread.
396             */
397            throw new ConcurrentModificationException("unitToLabel");
398        }
399        if (unitForOldLabel != null && !unitForOldLabel.getSystemUnit().equals(unit.getSystemUnit())) {
400            /*
401             * Assuming there is no bug in our algorithm, this exception should never happen
402             * unless this UnitFormat has been modified concurrently in another thread.
403             * We compared system units because the units may not be strictly equal
404             * as a result of the call to ConventionalUnit.forSymbol(label).
405             */
406            throw new ConcurrentModificationException("labelToUnit");
407        }
408    }
409
410    /**
411     * Loads the {@code UnitNames} resource bundle for the given locale.
412     */
413    static ResourceBundle getBundle(final Locale locale) {
414        return ResourceBundle.getBundle("tech.uom.seshat.UnitNames", locale, UnitFormat.class.getClassLoader());
415    }
416
417    /**
418     * Returns the mapping from unit symbols to long localized names.
419     * This mapping is loaded when first needed and memorized as long as the locale does not change.
420     */
421    private ResourceBundle symbolToName() {
422        ResourceBundle r = symbolToName;
423        if (r == null) {
424            symbolToName = r = getBundle(locale);
425        }
426        return r;
427    }
428
429    /**
430     * Returns the unit instance for the given long (un)localized name.
431     * This method is somewhat the converse of {@link #symbolToName()}, but recognizes also
432     * international and American spelling of unit names in addition of localized names.
433     * The intent is to recognize "meter" as well as "metre".
434     *
435     * <p>While we said that {@code UnitFormat} is not thread safe, we make an exception for this method
436     * for allowing the singleton {@link #INSTANCE} to parse symbols in a multi-threads environment.</p>
437     *
438     * @param  uom  the unit symbol, without leading or trailing spaces.
439     * @return the unit for the given name, or {@code null} if unknown.
440     */
441    private Unit<?> fromName(String uom) {
442        /*
443         * Before to search in resource bundles, check for degrees units. The "deg" unit can be both angular
444         * and Celsius degrees. We try to resolve this ambiguity by looking for the "C" suffix. We perform a
445         * special case for the degrees units because SI symbols are case-sentive and unit names in resource
446         * bundles are case-insensitive, but the "deg" case is a mix of both.
447         */
448        final int length = uom.length();
449        for (int i=0; ; i++) {
450            if (i != DEGREES.length()) {
451                if (i != length && (uom.charAt(i) | ('a' - 'A')) == DEGREES.charAt(i)) {
452                    continue;                           // Loop as long as the characters are the same, ignoring case.
453                }
454                if (i != 3 && i != 6) {
455                    break;                              // Exit if not "deg" (3) or "degree" (6 characters).
456                }
457            }
458            if (length == i) {
459                return Units.DEGREE;                    // Exactly "deg", "degree" or "degrees" (ignoring case).
460            }
461            final int c = uom.codePointAt(i);
462            if (c == '_' || Character.isSpaceChar(c)) {
463                i += Character.charCount(c);            // Ignore space in "degree C", "deg C", "deg K", etc.
464            }
465            if (length - i == 1) {
466                switch (uom.charAt(i)) {
467                    case 'K':                           // Unicode U+212A
468                    case 'K': return Units.KELVIN;      // "degK" (ignoring case except for 'K')
469                    case 'C': return Units.CELSIUS;
470                    case 'N':                           // degree_N, degrees_N, degreeN, degreesN.
471                    case 'E': return Units.DEGREE;      // degree_E, degrees_E, degreeE, degreesE.
472                }
473            }
474            break;
475        }
476        /*
477         * At this point, we determined that the given unit symbol is not degrees (of angle or of temperature).
478         * Remaining code is generic to all other kinds of units: a check in a HashMap loaded when first needed.
479         */
480        Map<String,Unit<?>> map = nameToUnit;
481        if (map == null) {
482            map = SHARED.get(locale);
483            if (map == null) {
484                map = new HashMap<>(128);
485                copy(locale, symbolToName(), map);
486                if (!locale.equals(Locale.US))   copy(Locale.US,   getBundle(Locale.US),   map);
487                if (!locale.equals(Locale.ROOT)) copy(Locale.ROOT, getBundle(Locale.ROOT), map);
488                /*
489                 * The UnitAliases file contains names that are not unit symbols and are not included in the UnitNames
490                 * property files neither. It contains longer names sometime used (for example "decimal degree" instead
491                 * of "degree"), some plural forms (for example "feet" instead of "foot") and a few common misspellings
492                 * (for exemple "Celcius" instead of "Celsius").
493                 */
494                final ResourceBundle r = ResourceBundle.getBundle("tech.uom.seshat.UnitAliases", locale, UnitFormat.class.getClassLoader());
495                for (final String name : r.keySet()) {
496                    map.put(name.intern(), Units.get(r.getString(name)));
497                }
498                map = Collections.unmodifiableMap(map);
499                /*
500                 * Cache the map so we can share it with other UnitFormat instances.
501                 * Sharing is safe if the map is unmodifiable.
502                 */
503                synchronized (SHARED) {
504                    for (final Map<String,Unit<?>> existing : SHARED.values()) {
505                        if (map.equals(existing)) {
506                            map = existing;
507                            break;
508                        }
509                    }
510                    SHARED.put(locale, map);
511                }
512            }
513            nameToUnit = map;
514        }
515        /*
516         * The 'nameToUnit' map contains plural forms (declared in UnitAliases.properties),
517         * but we make a special case for "degrees", "metres" and "meters" because they
518         * appear in numerous places.
519         */
520        uom = uom.replace('_', ' ').toLowerCase(locale);
521        uom = CharSequences.replace(CharSequences.replace(CharSequences.replace(CharSequences.toASCII(uom),
522                "meters",  "meter"),
523                "metres",  "metre"),
524                 DEGREES,  "degree").toString();
525        /*
526         * Returns the unit with application of the power if it is part of the name.
527         * For example this method interprets "meter2" as "meter" raised to power 2.
528         */
529        Unit<?> unit = map.get(uom);
530appPow: if (unit == null) {
531            int s = uom.length();
532            if (--s > 0 && isDigit(uom.charAt(s))) {
533                do if (--s < 0) break appPow;
534                while (isDigit(uom.charAt(s)));
535                if (uom.charAt(s) == '-') {
536                    if (--s < 0) break appPow;
537                }
538                unit = map.get(uom.substring(0, ++s));
539                if (unit != null) {
540                    unit = unit.pow(Integer.parseInt(uom.substring(s)));
541                }
542            }
543        }
544        return unit;
545    }
546
547    /**
548     * Copies all entries from the given "symbols to names" mapping to the given "names to units" mapping.
549     * During this copy, keys are converted from symbols to names and values are converted from symbols to
550     * {@code Unit} instance. We use {@code Unit} values instead of their symbols because all {@code Unit}
551     * instances are created at {@link Units} class initialization anyway (so we do not create new instance
552     * here), and it avoid to retain references to the {@link String} instances loaded by the resource bundle.
553     */
554    private static void copy(final Locale locale, final ResourceBundle symbolToName, final Map<String,Unit<?>> nameToUnit) {
555        for (final String symbol : symbolToName.keySet()) {
556            nameToUnit.put(CharSequences.toASCII(symbolToName.getString(symbol).toLowerCase(locale)).toString().intern(), Units.get(symbol));
557        }
558    }
559
560    /**
561     * Formats the specified unit.
562     * This method performs the first of the following actions that can be done.
563     *
564     * <ol>
565     *   <li>If a {@linkplain #label(Unit, String) label has been specified} for the given unit,
566     *       then that label is appended unconditionally.</li>
567     *   <li>Otherwise if the formatting style is {@link Style#NAME} and the {@link Unit#getName()} method
568     *       returns a non-null value, then that value is appended. {@code Unit} instances implemented by
569     *       Seshat are handled in a special way for localizing the name according the
570     *       {@linkplain #setLocale(Locale) locale specified to this format}.</li>
571     *   <li>Otherwise if the {@link Unit#getSymbol()} method returns a non-null value,
572     *       then that value is appended.</li>
573     *   <li>Otherwise a default symbol is created from the entries returned by {@link Unit#getBaseUnits()}.</li>
574     * </ol>
575     *
576     * @param  unit        the unit to format.
577     * @param  toAppendTo  where to format the unit.
578     * @return the given {@code toAppendTo} argument, for method calls chaining.
579     * @throws IOException if an error occurred while writing to the destination.
580     */
581    @Override
582    public Appendable format(final Unit<?> unit, final Appendable toAppendTo) throws IOException {
583        Objects.requireNonNull(unit);
584        Objects.requireNonNull(toAppendTo);
585        /*
586         * Choice 1: label specified by a call to label(Unit, String).
587         */
588        {
589            final String label = unitToLabel.get(unit);
590            if (label != null) {
591                return toAppendTo.append(label);
592            }
593        }
594        /*
595         * Choice 2: value specified by Unit.getName(). We skip this check if the given Unit is an instance
596         * implemented by Seshat because  AbstractUnit.getName()  delegates to the same resource bundle
597         * than the one used by this block. We are better to use the resource bundle of the UnitFormat both
598         * for performance reasons and because the locale may not be the same.
599         */
600        if (style == Style.NAME) {
601            if (!(unit instanceof AbstractUnit)) {
602                final String label = unit.getName();
603                if (label != null) {
604                    return toAppendTo.append(label);
605                }
606            } else {
607                String label = unit.getSymbol();
608                if (label != null) {
609                    if (label.isEmpty()) {
610                        label = UNITY;
611                    }
612                    // Following is not thread-safe, but it is okay since we do not use INSTANCE for unit names.
613                    final ResourceBundle names = symbolToName();
614                    try {
615                        label = names.getString(label);
616                    } catch (MissingResourceException e) {
617                        // Name not found; use the symbol as a fallback.
618                    }
619                    return toAppendTo.append(label);
620                }
621            }
622        }
623        /*
624         * Choice 3: if the unit has a specific symbol, appends that symbol.
625         * Seshat implementation uses Unicode characters in the symbol, which are not valid for UCUM.
626         * But Styme.UCUM.appendSymbol(…) performs required replacements.
627         */
628        {
629            final String symbol = unit.getSymbol();
630            if (symbol != null) {
631                return style.appendSymbol(toAppendTo, symbol);
632            }
633        }
634        /*
635         * Choice 4: if all the above failed, fallback on a symbol created from the base units and their power.
636         * Note that this may produce more verbose symbols than needed because derived units like Volt or Watt
637         * are decomposed into their base SI units. The scale factor will be inserted before the unit components,
638         * e.g. "30⋅m∕s". Note that a scale factor relative to system unit may not be what we want if the unit
639         * contains "kg", since it block us from using SI prefixes. But in many cases (not all), a symbol will
640         * have been created by SystemUnit.transform(…), in which case "Choice 3" above would have been executed.
641         */
642        final Unit<?> unscaled = unit.getSystemUnit();
643        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")          // Both 'unit' and 'unscaled' are 'Unit<Q>'.
644        final double scale = AbstractConverter.scale(unit.getConverterTo((Unit) unscaled));
645        if (Double.isNaN(scale)) {
646            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonRatioUnit_1,
647                    "?⋅" + Style.OPEN + unscaled + Style.CLOSE));
648        }
649        /*
650         * In addition of the scale, we will need to know:
651         *
652         *   - The components (for example "m" and "s" in "m∕s").
653         *   - Whether we have at least one component on the left side of "∕" operation.
654         *     Used for determining if we should prepend "1" before the "∕" symbol.
655         *   - If there is exactly one component on the left side of "∕" and that component
656         *     is prefixable, the power raising that component. Used for choosing a prefix.
657         */
658        int prefixPower = 0;
659        boolean hasNumerator = false;
660        final Map<? extends Unit<?>, ? extends Number> components;
661        if (unscaled instanceof AbstractUnit<?>) {
662            // In Seshat implementation, power may be fractional.
663            final Map<SystemUnit<?>, Fraction> c = ((AbstractUnit<?>) unscaled).getBaseSystemUnits();
664            components = c;
665            for (final Map.Entry<SystemUnit<?>, Fraction> e : c.entrySet()) {
666                final Fraction power = e.getValue();
667                if (power.signum() > 0) {
668                    hasNumerator = true;
669                    if (prefixPower == 0 && power.denominator == 1 && e.getKey().isPrefixable()) {
670                        prefixPower = power.numerator;
671                    } else {
672                        prefixPower = 0;
673                        break;
674                    }
675                }
676            }
677        } else {
678            // Fallback for foreigner implementations (power restricted to integer).
679            Map<? extends Unit<?>, Integer> c = unscaled.getBaseUnits();
680            if (c == null) c = Collections.singletonMap(unit, 1);
681            components = c;
682            for (final Map.Entry<? extends Unit<?>, Integer> e : c.entrySet()) {
683                final int power = e.getValue();
684                if (power > 0) {
685                    hasNumerator = true;
686                    if (prefixPower == 0 && AbstractUnit.isPrefixable(e.getKey())) {
687                        prefixPower = power;
688                    } else {
689                        prefixPower = 0;
690                        break;
691                    }
692                }
693            }
694        }
695        /*
696         * Append the scale factor. If we can use a prefix (e.g. "km" instead of "1000⋅m"), we will do that.
697         * Otherwise if the scale is a power of 10 and we are allowed to use Unicode symbols, we will write
698         * for example 10⁵⋅m instead of 100000⋅m. If the scale is not a power of 10, or if we are requested
699         * to format UCUM symbol, then we fallback on the usual 'Double.toString(double)' representation.
700         */
701        if (scale != 1) {
702            final char prefix = Prefixes.symbol(scale, prefixPower);
703            if (prefix != 0) {
704                toAppendTo.append(Prefixes.concat(prefix, ""));
705            } else {
706                boolean asPowerOf10 = (style != Style.UCUM);
707                if (asPowerOf10) {
708                    double power = Math.log10(scale);
709                    asPowerOf10 = AbstractConverter.epsilonEquals(power, power = Math.round(power));
710                    if (asPowerOf10) {
711                        toAppendTo.append("10");
712                        final String text = Integer.toString((int) power);
713                        for (int i=0; i<text.length(); i++) {
714                            toAppendTo.append(Characters.toSuperScript(text.charAt(i)));
715                        }
716                    }
717                }
718                if (!asPowerOf10) {
719                    final String text = Double.toString(scale);
720                    int length = text.length();
721                    if (text.endsWith(".0")) length -= 2;
722                    toAppendTo.append(text, 0, length);
723                }
724                /*
725                 * The 'formatComponents' method appends division symbol only, no multiplication symbol.
726                 * If we have formatted a scale factor and there is at least one component to multiply,
727                 * we need to append the multiplication symbol ourselves. Note that 'formatComponents'
728                 * put numerators before denominators, so we are sure that the first term after the
729                 * multiplication symbol is a numerator.
730                 */
731                if (hasNumerator) {
732                    toAppendTo.append(style.multiply);
733                }
734            }
735        } else if (!hasNumerator) {
736            toAppendTo.append('1');
737        }
738        formatComponents(components, style, toAppendTo);
739        return toAppendTo;
740    }
741
742    /**
743     * Creates a new symbol (e.g. "m/s") from the given symbols and factors.
744     * Keys in the given map can be either {@link Unit} or {@link Dimension} instances.
745     * Values in the given map are either {@link Integer} or {@link Fraction} instances.
746     *
747     * @param  components  the components of the symbol to format.
748     * @param  style       whether to allow Unicode characters.
749     * @param  toAppendTo  where to write the symbol.
750     */
751    static void formatComponents(final Map<?, ? extends Number> components, final Style style, final Appendable toAppendTo)
752            throws IOException
753    {
754        boolean isFirst = true;
755        final List<Map.Entry<?,? extends Number>> deferred = new ArrayList<>(components.size());
756        for (final Map.Entry<?,? extends Number> entry : components.entrySet()) {
757            final Number power = entry.getValue();
758            final int n = (power instanceof Fraction) ? ((Fraction) power).numerator : power.intValue();
759            if (n > 0) {
760                if (!isFirst) {
761                    toAppendTo.append(style.multiply);
762                }
763                isFirst = false;
764                formatComponent(entry, false, style, toAppendTo);
765            } else if (n != 0) {
766                deferred.add(entry);
767            }
768        }
769        /*
770         * At this point, all numerators have been appended. Now append the denominators together.
771         * For example pressure dimension is formatted as M∕(L⋅T²) no matter if 'M' was the first
772         * dimension in the given 'components' map or not.
773         */
774        if (!deferred.isEmpty()) {
775            toAppendTo.append(style.divide);
776            final boolean useParenthesis = (deferred.size() > 1);
777            if (useParenthesis) {
778                toAppendTo.append(Style.OPEN);
779            }
780            isFirst = true;
781            for (final Map.Entry<?,? extends Number> entry : deferred) {
782                if (!isFirst) {
783                    toAppendTo.append(style.multiply);
784                }
785                isFirst = false;
786                formatComponent(entry, true, style, toAppendTo);
787            }
788            if (useParenthesis) {
789                toAppendTo.append(Style.CLOSE);
790            }
791        }
792    }
793
794    /**
795     * Formats a single unit or dimension raised to the given power.
796     *
797     * @param  entry    the base unit or base dimension to format, together with its power.
798     * @param  inverse  {@code true} for inverting the power sign.
799     * @param  style    whether to allow Unicode characters.
800     */
801    private static void formatComponent(final Map.Entry<?,? extends Number> entry, final boolean inverse,
802            final Style style, final Appendable toAppendTo) throws IOException
803    {
804        formatSymbol(entry.getKey(), style, toAppendTo);
805        final Number power = entry.getValue();
806        int n;
807        if (power instanceof Fraction) {
808            Fraction f = (Fraction) power;
809            if (f.denominator != 1) {
810                if (inverse) {
811                    f = f.negate();
812                }
813                style.appendPower(toAppendTo, f);
814                return;
815            }
816            n = f.numerator;
817        } else {
818            n = power.intValue();
819        }
820        if (inverse) n = -n;
821        if (n != 1) {
822            style.appendPower(toAppendTo, n);
823        }
824    }
825
826    /**
827     * Appends the symbol for the given base unit of base dimension, or "?" if no symbol was found.
828     * If the given object is a unit, then it should be an instance of {@link SystemUnit}.
829     *
830     * @param  base        the base unit or base dimension to format.
831     * @param  style       whether to allow Unicode characters.
832     * @param  toAppendTo  where to append the symbol.
833     */
834    private static void formatSymbol(final Object base, final Style style, final Appendable toAppendTo) throws IOException {
835        if (base instanceof UnitDimension) {
836            final char symbol = ((UnitDimension) base).symbol;
837            if (symbol != 0) {
838                toAppendTo.append(symbol);
839                return;
840            }
841        }
842        if (base instanceof Unit<?>) {
843            final String symbol = ((Unit<?>) base).getSymbol();
844            if (symbol != null) {
845                style.appendSymbol(toAppendTo, symbol);
846                return;
847            }
848        }
849        toAppendTo.append('?');
850    }
851
852    /**
853     * Formats the specified unit in the given buffer.
854     * This method delegates to {@link #format(Unit, Appendable)}.
855     *
856     * @param  unit        the unit to format.
857     * @param  toAppendTo  where to format the unit.
858     * @param  pos         where to store the position of a formatted field.
859     * @return the given {@code toAppendTo} argument, for method calls chaining.
860     */
861    @Override
862    public StringBuffer format(final Object unit, final StringBuffer toAppendTo, final FieldPosition pos) {
863        try {
864            return (StringBuffer) format((Unit<?>) unit, toAppendTo);
865        } catch (IOException e) {
866            throw new AssertionError(e);      // Should never happen since we are writting to a StringBuffer.
867        }
868    }
869
870    /**
871     * Formats the given unit.
872     * This method delegates to {@link #format(Unit, Appendable)}.
873     *
874     * @param  unit  the unit to format.
875     * @return the formatted unit.
876     */
877    @Override
878    public String format(final Unit<?> unit) {
879        try {
880            return format(unit, new StringBuilder()).toString();
881        } catch (IOException e) {
882            throw new AssertionError(e);      // Should never happen since we are writting to a StringBuilder.
883        }
884    }
885
886    /**
887     * Returns {@code 0} or {@code 1} if the {@code '*'} character at the given index stands for exponentiation
888     * instead than multiplication, or a negative value if the character stands for multiplication. This check
889     * is used for heuristic rules at parsing time. Current implementation applies the following rules:
890     *
891     * <ul>
892     *   <li>The operation is presumed an exponentiation if the '*' symbol is doubled, as in {@code "m**s-1"}.</li>
893     *   <li>The operation is presumed an exponentiation if it is surrounded by digits or a sign on its right side.
894     *       Example: {@code "10*-6"}, which means 1E-6 in UCUM syntax.</li>
895     *   <li>All other cases are currently presumed multiplication.
896     *       Example: {@code "m*s"}.</li>
897     * </ul>
898     *
899     * @return -1 for parsing as a multiplication, or a positive value for exponentiation.
900     *         If positive, this is the number of characters in the exponent symbol minus 1.
901     */
902    private static int exponentOperator(final CharSequence symbols, int i, final int length) {
903        if (i >= 0 && ++i < length) {
904            final char c = symbols.charAt(i);           // No need for code point because next conditions are true only in BMP.
905            if (c == Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY) {
906                return 1;                               // "**" operator: need to skip one character after '*'.
907            }
908            if ((isDigit(c) || isSign(c)) && isDigit(symbols.charAt(i-2))) {
909                return 0;                               // "*" operator surrounded by digits: no character to skip.
910            }
911        }
912        return -1;
913    }
914
915    /**
916     * Returns {@code true} if the {@code '.'} character at the given index is surrounded by digits or
917     * is at the beginning or the end of the character sequences. This check is used for heuristic rules.
918     *
919     * @see Style#UCUM
920     */
921    private static boolean isDecimalSeparator(final CharSequence symbols, int i, final int length) {
922        return (i   == 0      || isDigit(symbols.charAt(i-1)) &&
923               (++i >= length || isDigit(symbols.charAt(i))));
924    }
925
926    /**
927     * Returns {@code true} if the given character is a digit in the sense of the {@code UnitFormat} parser.
928     * Note that "digit" is taken here in a much more restrictive way than {@link Character#isDigit(int)}.
929     *
930     * <p>A return value of {@code true} guarantees that the given character is in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP).
931     * Consequently the {@code c} argument value does not need to be the result of {@link String#codePointAt(int)};
932     * the result of {@link String#charAt(int)} is sufficient. We nevertheless use the {@code int} type for avoiding
933     * the need to cast if caller uses code points for another reason.</p>
934     *
935     * @see Character#isBmpCodePoint(int)
936     */
937    private static boolean isDigit(final int c) {
938        return c >= '0' && c <= '9';
939    }
940
941    /**
942     * Returns {@code true} if the given character is the sign of a number according the {@code UnitFormat} parser.
943     * A return value of {@code true} guarantees that the given character is in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP).
944     * Consequently the {@code c} argument value does not need to be the result of {@link String#codePointAt(int)}.
945     */
946    private static boolean isSign(final int c) {
947        return c == '+' || c == '-';
948    }
949
950    /**
951     * Returns {@code true} if the given character is the sign of a division operator.
952     * A return value of {@code true} guarantees that the given character is in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP).
953     * Consequently the {@code c} argument value does not need to be the result of {@link String#codePointAt(int)}.
954     */
955    private static boolean isDivisor(final int c) {
956        return c == '/' || c == AbstractUnit.DIVIDE;
957    }
958
959    /**
960     * Returns {@code true} if the given character sequence contains at least one digit.
961     * This is a hack for allowing to recognize units like "100 feet" (in principle not
962     * legal, but seen in practice). This verification has some value if digits are not
963     * allowed as unit label or symbol.
964     */
965    private static boolean hasDigit(final CharSequence symbol, int lower, final int upper) {
966        while (lower < upper) {
967            if (isDigit(symbol.charAt(lower++))) {
968                return true;
969            }
970        }
971        return false;
972    }
973
974    /**
975     * Parse position when text to be parsed is expected to contain nothing else than a unit symbol.
976     * This is used for recording whether another term (separated from the previous term by a space)
977     * is allowed or not.
978     */
979    private static final class Position extends ParsePosition {
980        /** {@code true} if we do not expect any more content after the last term parsed. */
981        boolean finished;
982
983        /** Creates a new position initialized to the beginning of the text to parse. */
984        Position() {
985            super(0);
986        }
987    }
988
989    /**
990     * Reports that the parsing is finished and no more content should be parsed.
991     * This method is invoked when the last parsed term is possibly one or more words instead than unit symbols.
992     * The intent is to avoid trying to parse "degree minute" as "degree × minute". By contrast, this method is
993     * not invoked if the string to parse is "m kg**-2" because it can be interpreted as "m × kg**-2".
994     */
995    private static void finish(final ParsePosition pos) {
996        if (pos instanceof Position) {
997            ((Position) pos).finished = true;
998        }
999    }
1000
1001    /**
1002     * Parses the given text as an instance of {@code Unit}.
1003     * If the parse completes without reading the entire length of the text, an exception is thrown.
1004     *
1005     * <p>The parsing is lenient: symbols can be products or quotients of units like “m∕s”,
1006     * or words like “meters per second”.
1007     * The product operator can be either {@code '.'} (ASCII) or {@code '⋅'} (Unicode) character.
1008     * Exponent after symbol can be decimal digits as in “m2” or a superscript as in “m²”.</p>
1009     *
1010     * <p>This method differs from {@link #parse(CharSequence, ParsePosition)} in the treatment of white spaces:
1011     * that method with a {@link ParsePosition} argument stops parsing at the first white space,
1012     * while this {@code parse(…)} method treats white spaces as multiplications.
1013     * The reason for this difference is that white space is normally not a valid multiplication symbol;
1014     * it could be followed by a text which is not part of the unit symbol.
1015     * But in the case of this {@code parse(CharSequence)} method, the whole {@code CharSequence} shall be a unit symbol.
1016     * In such case, white spaces are less ambiguous.</p>
1017     *
1018     * <p>The default implementation delegates to
1019     * <code>{@linkplain #parse(CharSequence, ParsePosition) parse}(symbols, new ParsePosition(0))</code>
1020     * and verifies that all non-white characters have been parsed.
1021     * Units separated by spaces are multiplied; for example "kg m**-2" is parsed as kg/m².</p>
1022     *
1023     * @param  symbols  the unit symbols or URI to parse.
1024     * @return the unit parsed from the specified symbols.
1025     * @throws ParserException if a problem occurred while parsing the given symbols.
1026     *
1027     * @see Units#valueOf(String)
1028     */
1029    @Override
1030    public Unit<?> parse(final CharSequence symbols) throws ParserException {
1031        final Position position = new Position();
1032        Unit<?> unit = parse(symbols, position);
1033        final int length = symbols.length();
1034        int unrecognized;
1035        while ((unrecognized = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, position.getIndex(), length)) < length) {
1036            if (position.finished || !Character.isLetter(Character.codePointAt(symbols, unrecognized))) {
1037                throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnexpectedCharactersAfter_2,
1038                        CharSequences.trimWhitespaces(symbols, 0, unrecognized),
1039                        CharSequences.trimWhitespaces(symbols, unrecognized, length)),
1040                        symbols, unrecognized);
1041            }
1042            position.setIndex(unrecognized);
1043            unit = unit.multiply(parse(symbols, position));
1044        }
1045        return unit;
1046    }
1047
1048    /**
1049     * Parses a portion of the given text as an instance of {@code Unit}.
1050     * Parsing begins at the index given by {@link ParsePosition#getIndex()}.
1051     * After parsing, the above-cited index is updated to the first unparsed character.
1052     *
1053     * <p>The parsing is lenient: symbols can be products or quotients of units like “m∕s”,
1054     * or words like “meters per second”.
1055     * The product operator can be either {@code '.'} (ASCII) or {@code '⋅'} (Unicode) character.
1056     * Exponent after symbol can be decimal digits as in “m2” or a superscript as in “m²”.</p>
1057     *
1058     * <p>Note that contrarily to {@link #parseObject(String, ParsePosition)}, this method never return {@code null}.
1059     * If an error occurs at parsing time, an unchecked {@link ParserException} is thrown.</p>
1060     *
1061     * @param  symbols  the unit symbols to parse.
1062     * @param  position on input, index of the first character to parse.
1063     *                  On output, index after the last parsed character.
1064     * @return the unit parsed from the specified symbols.
1065     * @throws ParserException if a problem occurred while parsing the given symbols.
1066     */
1067    @SuppressWarnings({"null", "fallthrough"})
1068    public Unit<?> parse(CharSequence symbols, final ParsePosition position) throws ParserException {
1069        Objects.requireNonNull(symbols);
1070        Objects.requireNonNull(position);
1071        int end   = symbols.length();
1072        int start = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, position.getIndex(), end);
1073        /*
1074         * Split the unit around the multiplication and division operators and parse each term individually.
1075         * Note that exponentation need to be kept as part of a single unit symbol.
1076         *
1077         * The 'start' variable is the index of the first character of the next unit term to parse.
1078         */
1079        final Operation operation = new Operation(symbols);    // Enumeration value: NOOP, IMPLICIT, MULTIPLY, DIVIDE.
1080        Unit<?> unit = null;
1081        boolean hasSpaces = false;
1082        int i = start;
1083scan:   for (int n; i < end; i += n) {
1084            final int c = Character.codePointAt(symbols, i);
1085            n = Character.charCount(c);
1086            final int next;
1087            switch (c) {
1088                /*
1089                 * The minus sign can be both part of a number or part of a symbol. If the minus sign if followed
1090                 * by a digit, then handle it as part of a number, in which case the action is only "continue".
1091                 * Otherwise handle as part of a symbol, in which case the action is in the default case below.
1092                 * The intent is to prevent the replacement of Operation.IMPLICIT by Operation.MULTIPLY in symbol
1093                 * like "(m²⋅s)-1" because we want the "-1" part to be handled as Operation.EXPONENT instead.
1094                 */
1095                case '-': {
1096                    if (i + n < end && Character.isDigit(Character.codePointAt(symbols, i + n))) {
1097                        continue;
1098                    }
1099                    // else fall through.
1100                }
1101                /*
1102                 * For any character that are is not an operator or parenthesis, either continue the scanning of
1103                 * characters or stop it, depending on whether the character is valid for a unit symbol or not.
1104                 * In the later case, we consider that we reached the end of a unit symbol.
1105                 */
1106                default:  {
1107                    if (AbstractUnit.isSymbolChar(c)) {
1108                        if (operation.code == Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1109                            operation.code =  Operation.MULTIPLY;
1110                        }
1111                        continue;
1112                    }
1113                    if (Character.isDigit(c) || Characters.isSuperScript(c)) {
1114                        continue;
1115                    }
1116                    if (Character.isSpaceChar(c)) {                         // NOT Character.isWhitespace(int)
1117                        hasSpaces = true;
1118                        continue;
1119                    }
1120                    break scan;
1121                }
1122                /*
1123                 * Star is for exponentiation in UCUM syntax, but some symbols may use it for unit multiplication.
1124                 * We interpret the symbol as a multiplication if the characters before or after it seem to be for
1125                 * a unit symbol.
1126                 */
1127                case Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY: {
1128                    final int w = exponentOperator(symbols, i, end);
1129                    if (w < 0) {
1130                        next = Operation.MULTIPLY;
1131                        break;
1132                    }
1133                    i += w;
1134                    // else fall through.
1135                }
1136                case Style.EXPONENT: {
1137                    if (operation.code == Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1138                        next = Operation.EXPONENT;
1139                        break;
1140                    }
1141                    continue;
1142                }
1143                /*
1144                 * The period is the multiplication operator in UCUM format. According UCUM there is no ambiguity
1145                 * with the decimal separator since unit terms should not contain floating point numbers. However
1146                 * we relax this rule in order to support scale factor of angular units (e.g. π/180).  The period
1147                 * is interpreted as a decimal separator if there is a decimal digit before and after it.
1148                 */
1149                case '.': if (isDecimalSeparator(symbols, i, end)) continue;
1150                case '×': // Fall through
1151                case AbstractUnit.MULTIPLY: next = Operation.MULTIPLY; break;
1152                case '÷':
1153                case '⁄': // Fraction slash
1154                case '/':
1155                case AbstractUnit.DIVIDE: next = Operation.DIVIDE; break;
1156                /*
1157                 * If we find an '(' parenthesis, invoke recursively this method for the part inside parenthesis.
1158                 * The parsing should end at the ')' parenthesis since it is not a valid unit symbol. If we do not
1159                 * find that closing parenthesis, this will be considered an error.
1160                 */
1161                case Style.OPEN: {
1162                    final int pos = i + Character.charCount(c);
1163                    final ParsePosition sub = new ParsePosition(pos);
1164                    final Unit<?> term = parse(symbols, sub);
1165                    i = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, sub.getIndex(), end);
1166                    if (i >= end || Character.codePointAt(symbols, i) != Style.CLOSE) {
1167                        throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NonEquilibratedParenthesis_2,
1168                               symbols.subSequence(start, i), Style.CLOSE), symbols, start);
1169                    }
1170                    unit = operation.apply(unit, term, pos);
1171                    operation.code = Operation.IMPLICIT;    // Default operation if there is no × or / symbols after parenthesis.
1172                    start = i + (n = 1);                    // Skip the number of characters in the '(' Unicode code point.
1173                    continue;
1174                }
1175            }
1176            /*
1177             * We reach this point only if we found some operator (division or multiplication).
1178             * If the operator has been found between two digits, we consider it as part of the
1179             * term. For example "m2/3" is considered as a single term where "2/3" is the exponent.
1180             */
1181            if (i > start && i+n < end
1182                    && Character.isDigit(Character.codePointBefore(symbols, i))
1183                    && Character.isDigit(Character.codePointAt(symbols, i+n)))
1184            {
1185                continue;
1186            }
1187            /*
1188             * At this point, we have either a first unit to parse (NOOP), or a multiplication or division to apply
1189             * between the previously parsed units and the next unit to parse. A special case is IMPLICIT, which is
1190             * a multiplication without explicit × symbol after the parenthesis. The implicit multiplication can be
1191             * overridden by an explicit × or / symbol, which is what happened if we reach this point (tip: look in
1192             * the above 'switch' statement all cases that end with 'break', not 'break scan' or 'continue').
1193             */
1194            if (operation.code != Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1195                unit = operation.apply(unit, parseTerm(symbols, start, i, operation), start);
1196            }
1197            hasSpaces = false;
1198            operation.code = next;
1199            start = i + n;
1200        }
1201        /*
1202         * At this point we either found an unrecognized character or reached the end of string. We will
1203         * parse the remaining characters as a unit and apply the pending unit operation (multiplication
1204         * or division). But before, we need to check if the parsing should stop at the first whitespace.
1205         * This verification assumes that spaces are allowed only in labels specified by the label(…)
1206         * method and in resource bundles, not in labels specified by AbstractUnit.alternate(String).
1207         */
1208        Unit<?> component = null;
1209        if (hasSpaces) {
1210            end = i;
1211            start = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(symbols, start, i);
1212search:     while ((i = CharSequences.skipTrailingWhitespaces(symbols, start, i)) > start) {
1213                final String uom = symbols.subSequence(start, i).toString();
1214                if ((component = labelToUnit.get(uom)) != null) break;
1215                if ((component =        fromName(uom)) != null) break;
1216                int j=i, c;
1217                do {
1218                    c = Character.codePointBefore(symbols, j);
1219                    j -= Character.charCount(c);
1220                    if (j <= start) break search;
1221                } while (!Character.isWhitespace(c));
1222                /*
1223                 * Really use Character.isWhitespace(c) above, not Character.isSpaceChar(c), because we want
1224                 * to exclude non-breaking spaces.   This block should be the only place in UnitFormat class
1225                 * where we use isWhitespace(c) instead of isSpaceChar(c).
1226                 */
1227                i = j;                  // Will become the index of first space after search loop completion.
1228            }
1229            /*
1230             * At this point we did not found any user-specified label or localized name matching the substring.
1231             * Assume that the parsing should stop at the first space, on the basis that spaces are not allowed
1232             * in unit symbols. We make an exception if we detect that the part before the first space contains
1233             * digits (not allowed in unit symbols neither), in which case the substring may be something like
1234             * "100 feet".
1235             */
1236            if (hasDigit(symbols, start, i)) {
1237                i = end;                        // Restore the full length (until the first illegal character).
1238            }
1239        }
1240        if (!(operation.finished = (component != null))) {
1241            component = parseTerm(symbols, start, i, operation);            // May set 'operation.finished' flag.
1242        }
1243        if (operation.finished) {
1244            finish(position);           // For preventing interpretation of "degree minute" as "degree × minute".
1245        }
1246        unit = operation.apply(unit, component, start);
1247        position.setIndex(i);
1248        return unit;
1249    }
1250
1251    /**
1252     * Represents an operation to be applied between two terms parsed by
1253     * {@link UnitFormat#parseTerm(CharSequence, int, int, Operation)}.
1254     */
1255    private static final class Operation {
1256        /**
1257         * Meaning of some characters parsed by {@link UnitFormat#parse(CharSequence)}.
1258         * The {@code IMPLICIT} case is a multiplication without symbol, which can be
1259         * overridden by an explicit × or / symbol.
1260         */
1261        static final int NOOP = 0, IMPLICIT = 1, MULTIPLY = 2, DIVIDE = 3, EXPONENT = 4;
1262
1263        /**
1264         * The operation as one of the {@link #NOOP}, {@link #IMPLICIT}, {@link #MULTIPLY}
1265         * or {@link #DIVIDE} values.
1266         */
1267        int code;
1268
1269        /**
1270         * The symbols being parsed. Used only for formatting error message if needed.
1271         */
1272        private final CharSequence symbols;
1273
1274        /**
1275         * {@code true} if the parsed terms may be one or more words, possibly containing white spaces.
1276         * In such case, the parsing should not continue after those words.
1277         *
1278         * @see Position#finished
1279         */
1280        boolean finished;
1281
1282        /**
1283         * Creates an operation initialized to {@link #NOOP}.
1284         */
1285        Operation(final CharSequence symbols) {
1286            this.symbols = symbols;
1287        }
1288
1289        /**
1290         * Applies a multiplication or division operation between the given units.
1291         *
1292         * @param  unit      the left operand, which is the unit parsed so far.
1293         * @param  term      the right operation, which is the newly parsed unit.
1294         * @param  position  the parse position to report if parsing fail.
1295         */
1296        Unit<?> apply(final Unit<?> unit, final Unit<?> term, final int position) {
1297            switch (code) {
1298                case NOOP:     return term;
1299                case IMPLICIT:
1300                case MULTIPLY: return unit.multiply(term);
1301                case DIVIDE:   return unit.divide(term);
1302                case EXPONENT: {
1303                    if (UnitDimension.isDimensionless(term.getDimension())) {
1304                        final String symbol = term.getSymbol();
1305                        if (symbol == null || symbol.isEmpty()) {
1306                            final double scale = Units.toStandardUnit(term);
1307                            final int power = (int) scale;
1308                            if (power == scale) {
1309                                return unit.pow(power);
1310                            }
1311                        }
1312                    }
1313                    throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.NotAnInteger_1, term), symbols, position);
1314                }
1315                default: throw new AssertionError(code);
1316            }
1317        }
1318
1319        /**
1320         * If this operation is a multiplication, replaces by division. Otherwise do nothing
1321         * (we do <strong>not</strong> replace division by multiplication). The intent is to
1322         * replace units like "m⋅s-1" by "m/s".
1323         *
1324         * @return whether the operation has been inverted.
1325         */
1326        boolean invert() {
1327            switch (code) {
1328                case IMPLICIT:
1329                case MULTIPLY: code = DIVIDE; return true;
1330                default: return false;
1331            }
1332        }
1333    }
1334
1335    /**
1336     * Parses a single unit symbol with its exponent.
1337     * The given symbol shall not contain multiplication or division operator except in exponent.
1338     * Parsing of fractional exponent as in "m2/3" is supported; other operations in the exponent
1339     * will cause an exception to be thrown.
1340     *
1341     * @param  symbols    the complete string specified by the user.
1342     * @param  lower      index where to begin parsing in the {@code symbols} string.
1343     * @param  upper      index after the last character to parse in the {@code symbols} string.
1344     * @param  operation  the operation to be applied (e.g. the term to be parsed is a multiplier or divisor of another unit).
1345     * @return the parsed unit symbol (never {@code null}).
1346     * @throws ParserException if a problem occurred while parsing the given symbols.
1347     */
1348    @SuppressWarnings("fallthrough")
1349    private Unit<?> parseTerm(final CharSequence symbols, final int lower, final int upper, final Operation operation)
1350            throws ParserException
1351    {
1352        final String uom = CharSequences.trimWhitespaces(symbols, lower, upper).toString();
1353        /*
1354         * Check for labels explicitly given by users. Those labels have precedence over the Seshat hard-coded
1355         * symbols. If no explicit label was found, check for symbols and names known to this UnitFormat instance.
1356         */
1357        Unit<?> unit = labelToUnit.get(uom);
1358        operation.finished = (unit != null);
1359        if (unit == null) {
1360            unit = Prefixes.getUnit(uom);
1361            if (unit == null) {
1362                final int length = uom.length();
1363                if (length == 0) {
1364                    return Units.UNITY;
1365                } else {
1366                    /*
1367                     * If the first character is a digit, presume that the term is a multiplication factor.
1368                     * The "*" character is used for raising the number on the left to the power on the right.
1369                     * Example: "10*6" is equal to one million. Seshat also handles the "^" character as "*".
1370                     *
1371                     * In principle, spaces are not allowed in unit symbols (in particular, UCUM specifies that
1372                     * spaces should not be interpreted as multication operators).  However in practice we have
1373                     * sometime units written in a form like "100 feet".
1374                     *
1375                     * If the last character is a super-script, then we assume a notation like "10⁻⁴".
1376                     */
1377                    final char c = uom.charAt(0);       // No need for code point because next condition is true only for BMP.
1378                    if (isDigit(c) || isSign(c)) {
1379                        final double multiplier;
1380                        try {
1381                            int s = uom.indexOf(' ');
1382                            if (s >= 0) {
1383                                final int next = CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(uom, s, length);
1384                                if (next < length && AbstractUnit.isSymbolChar(uom.codePointAt(next))) {
1385                                    operation.finished = true;  // For preventing attempt to continue parsing after "100 feet".
1386                                    multiplier = Double.parseDouble(uom.substring(0, s));
1387                                    return parseTerm(uom, s, length, new Operation(uom)).multiply(multiplier);
1388                                }
1389                            }
1390                            multiplier = parseMultiplicationFactor(uom);
1391                        } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
1392                            throw (ParserException) new ParserException(Errors.format(
1393                                    Errors.Keys.UnknownUnit_1, uom), symbols, lower).initCause(e);
1394                        }
1395                        if (operation.code == Operation.IMPLICIT) {
1396                            operation.code = Operation.EXPONENT;
1397                        }
1398                        return Units.UNITY.multiply(multiplier);
1399                    }
1400                }
1401                if (length >= 2) {
1402                    /*
1403                     * If the symbol ends with a digit (normal script or superscript), presume that this is the unit
1404                     * exponent.  That exponent can be a Unicode character (only one character in current UnitFormat
1405                     * implementation) or a number parseable with Integer.parseInt(String).
1406                     */
1407                    Fraction power = null;
1408                    int i = length;
1409                    int c = uom.codePointBefore(i);
1410                    i -= Character.charCount(c);
1411                    if (Characters.isSuperScript(c)) {
1412                        c = Characters.toNormalScript(c);
1413                        if (isDigit(c)) {
1414                            power = new Fraction(c - '0', 1);
1415                        }
1416                    } else if (isDigit(c)) {
1417                        while (i != 0) {
1418                            c = uom.codePointBefore(i);
1419                            final boolean isExponent = isDigit(c) || isDivisor(c);
1420                            if (isExponent || isSign(c)) {
1421                                i -= Character.charCount(c);
1422                            }
1423                            if (!isExponent) {
1424                                try {
1425                                    power = new Fraction(uom.substring(i));
1426                                } catch (NumberFormatException e) {
1427                                    // Should never happen unless the number is larger than 'int' capacity.
1428                                    throw (ParserException) new ParserException(Errors.format(
1429                                            Errors.Keys.UnknownUnit_1, uom), symbols, lower+i).initCause(e);
1430                                }
1431                                break;
1432                            }
1433                        }
1434                    }
1435                    if (power != null) {
1436                        /*
1437                         * At this point we have parsed the exponent. Before to parse the raw unit symbol,
1438                         * skip the exponent symbol (^, * or **) if any.
1439                         */
1440                        i = CharSequences.skipTrailingWhitespaces(uom, 0, i);
1441                        if (i != 0) {
1442                            // No need for code point because next conditions are true only in BMP.
1443                            switch (uom.charAt(i-1)) {
1444                                case Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY: {
1445                                    if (i != 1 && uom.charAt(i-2) == Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY) i--;
1446                                    // Fallthrough for skipping the next character and whitespaces.
1447                                }
1448                                case Style.EXPONENT: {
1449                                    i = CharSequences.skipTrailingWhitespaces(uom, 0, i - 1);
1450                                    break;
1451                                }
1452                            }
1453                        }
1454                        final String symbol = uom.substring(CharSequences.skipLeadingWhitespaces(uom, 0, i), i);
1455                        unit = labelToUnit.get(symbol);
1456                        operation.finished = (unit != null);
1457                        if (unit == null) {
1458                            unit = Prefixes.getUnit(symbol);
1459                        }
1460                        if (unit != null) {
1461                            int numerator   = power.numerator;
1462                            int denominator = power.denominator;
1463                            if (numerator < 0 && operation.invert()) {
1464                                numerator = -numerator;
1465                            }
1466                            if (numerator   != 1) unit = unit.pow (numerator);
1467                            if (denominator != 1) unit = unit.root(denominator);
1468                            return unit;
1469                        }
1470                    }
1471                }
1472                /*
1473                 * At this point, we have determined that the label is not a known unit symbol.
1474                 * It may be a unit name, in which case the label is not case-sensitive anymore.
1475                 */
1476                operation.finished = true;
1477                unit = fromName(uom);
1478                if (unit == null) {
1479                    if (CharSequences.regionMatches(symbols, lower, UNITY)) {
1480                        return Units.UNITY;
1481                    }
1482                    throw new ParserException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnknownUnit_1, uom), symbols, lower);
1483                }
1484            }
1485        }
1486        return unit;
1487    }
1488
1489    /**
1490     * Parses a multiplication factor, which may be a single number or a base raised to an exponent.
1491     * For example all the following strings are equivalent: "1000", "1000.0", "1E3", "10*3", "10^3", "10³".
1492     */
1493    private static double parseMultiplicationFactor(final String term) throws NumberFormatException {
1494        final String exponent;
1495        int s = term.lastIndexOf(Style.EXPONENT_OR_MULTIPLY);        // Check standard UCUM symbol first.
1496        if (s >= 0 || (s = term.lastIndexOf(Style.EXPONENT)) >= 0) {
1497            exponent = term.substring(s + 1);
1498        } else {
1499            s = term.length();
1500            int c = term.codePointBefore(s);
1501            if (!Characters.isSuperScript(c)) {
1502                return Double.parseDouble(term);                     // No exponent symbol and no superscript found.
1503            }
1504            // Example: "10⁻⁴". Split in base and exponent.
1505            final StringBuilder buffer = new StringBuilder(s);
1506            do {
1507                buffer.appendCodePoint(Characters.toNormalScript(c));
1508                if ((s -= Character.charCount(c)) <= 0) break;
1509                c = term.codePointBefore(s);
1510            } while (Characters.isSuperScript(c));
1511            exponent = buffer.reverse().toString();
1512        }
1513        final int base = Integer.parseInt(term.substring(0, s));
1514        final int exp  = Integer.parseInt(exponent);
1515        return (base == 10) ? MathFunctions.pow10(exp) : Math.pow(base, exp);
1516    }
1517
1518    /**
1519     * Parses text from a string to produce a unit. The default implementation delegates to {@link #parse(CharSequence)}
1520     * and wraps the {@link ParserException} into a {@link ParseException} for compatibility with {@code java.text} API.
1521     *
1522     * @param  source  the text, part of which should be parsed.
1523     * @return a unit parsed from the string.
1524     * @throws ParseException if the given string can not be fully parsed.
1525     */
1526    @Override
1527    public Object parseObject(final String source) throws ParseException {
1528        try {
1529            return parse(source);
1530        } catch (ParserException e) {
1531            throw (ParseException) new ParseException(e.getLocalizedMessage(), e.getPosition()).initCause(e);
1532        }
1533    }
1534
1535    /**
1536     * Parses text from a string to produce a unit, or returns {@code null} if the parsing failed.
1537     * The default implementation delegates to {@link #parse(CharSequence, ParsePosition)} and catches
1538     * the {@link ParserException}.
1539     *
1540     * @param  source  the text, part of which should be parsed.
1541     * @param  pos     index and error index information as described above.
1542     * @return a unit parsed from the string, or {@code null} in case of error.
1543     */
1544    @Override
1545    public Object parseObject(final String source, final ParsePosition pos) {
1546        try {
1547            return parse(source, pos);
1548        } catch (ParserException e) {
1549            pos.setErrorIndex(e.getPosition());
1550            return null;
1551        }
1552    }
1553
1554    /**
1555     * Returns a clone of this unit format. The new unit format will be initialized to the same
1556     * {@linkplain #getLocale() locale} and {@linkplain #label(Unit, String) labels} than this format.
1557     *
1558     * @return a clone of this unit format.
1559     */
1560    @Override
1561    public UnitFormat clone() {
1562        final UnitFormat f = (UnitFormat) super.clone();
1563        f.unitToLabel = clone(f.unitToLabel);
1564        return f;
1565    }
1566
1567    /**
1568     * Clones the given map, which can be either a {@link HashMap}
1569     * or the instance returned by {@link Collections#emptyMap()}.
1570     */
1571    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
1572    private static <K,V> Map<K,V> clone(final Map<K,V> value) {
1573        if (value instanceof HashMap<?,?>) {
1574            return (Map<K,V>) ((HashMap<?,?>) value).clone();
1575        } else {
1576            return new HashMap<>();
1577        }
1578    }
1579}
